column1: George Town is the capital city of the Malaysian state of Penang. George Town is Malaysia's third most populous city with 708
column2: 127 inhabitants as of 2010
column3: while Greater Penang is the nation's second largest conurbation in the country after Greater Kuala Lumpur with a population of 2
column5: 616. The historical core of George Town has been inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2008.Established as an entrepôt by Francis Light of the British East India Company in 1786
column6: George Town was the first British settlement in Southeast Asia. Together with Singapore and Malacca
column7: George Town formed part of the Straits Settlements
column8: which became a British crown colony in 1867. It was subjugated by Japan during World War II
column9: before being recaptured by the British at war's end. Shortly before Malaya attained independence from the British in 1957
column10: George Town was declared a city by Queen Elizabeth II
column11: making it the first city in the country's modern history.

column1: Due to the intermingling of the various ethnicities and religions that arrived on its shores
column2: George Town acquired a large eclectic assortment of colonial and Asian architectural styles. It also gained a reputation as Malaysia's gastronomic capital for its distinct and ubiquitous street food. Moreover
column3: the city hosts unique cultural heritage
column4: such as the Peranakans
column5: whose legacies are still visible on Penang's architecture and cuisine.

column1: The city of George Town includes the Bayan Lepas Free Industrial Zone
column2: a high-tech manufacturing hub regarded as the "Silicon Valley of the East". The city also serves as the financial centre of northern Malaysia and the nation's most vital medical tourism hub. Logistically
column3: the Penang International Airport links George Town with several major regional cities
column4: while a ferry service
column5: the Penang Bridge and the Second Penang Bridge connect the city with the rest of Peninsular Malaysia. Meanwhile
column6: George Town's Swettenham Pier has emerged as the busiest port of call in Malaysia for cruise ships.

column2: the British East India Company instructed Francis Light
column3: a British Royal Navy captain
column4: to form trade relations in the Malay Peninsula. Light subsequently landed in Kedah
column5: a Siamese vassal state threatened by both Siam and Burma
column6: as well as an internal Bugis revolt. Aware of this situation
column7: Light formed friendly relations with the then Sultan of Kedah
column8: Sultan Muhammad Jiwa Zainal Adilin II
column9: and promised British military protection
column10: while the Sultan reciprocally offered Penang Island
column11: then part of Kedah.Although Light subsequently reported on this offer to his superiors
column12: it was only in 1786 when he was finally ordered to obtain Penang Island from Kedah. The British East India Company sought control of the island as a Royal Navy base
column13: and as a trading post between China and India. To that end
column14: Light negotiated with the new Sultan of Kedah
column16: regarding the cession of the island to the British East India Company in exchange for British military aid. After an agreement was signed between Light and the Sultan
column17: Light and his entourage sailed on to Penang Island
column18: where they arrived on 17 July 1786.The area where Light first landed
column20: was originally a swamp covered in thick jungle. Once the area was cleared
column21: a simple ceremony was held on 11 August
column22: during which the Union Jack was raised. Penang Island was renamed the Prince of Wales Island after the heir to the British throne
column23: while the new settlement of George Town was created in honour of King George III.Light developed George Town as a free port
column24: thus allowing merchants to trade without having to pay any form of tax or duties. The policy's intent was to entice traders from the Dutch ports in the region. The number of incoming vessels rose from 85 in 1786 to 3
column25: 569 in 1802; George Town's population had also increased to 10
column26: 000 by 1792.A committee of assessors was established in 1800
column27: making it the first local council to be established in British Malaya. Meanwhile
column28: a Supreme Court was established at Fort Cornwallis in 1808.

column2: Penang Island became a centre of spice production within Southeast Asia. Spices such as nutmeg
column3: clove and pepper
column4: produced from the spice farms throughout the island
column5: were exported via the Port of Penang in George Town. The spice trade also allowed the British East India Company to cover the administrative costs of Penang.In 1826
column6: George Town was made the capital of the Straits Settlements
column7: an administrative polity that was also composed of Singapore and Malacca. However
column8: the capital was then shifted to Singapore in 1832
column9: as the latter had usurped George Town's position as the region's preeminent harbour.

column2: George Town retained its importance as a vital British entrepôt. Due to the opening of the Suez Canal
column3: the advent of steam ships and a tin mining boom in the Malay Peninsula
column4: the Port of Penang became a major tin-exporting harbour. By the end of the 19th century
column5: as mercantile firms and banks
column6: including Standard Chartered and HSBC
column7: flocked into George Town
column8: the city also evolved into a leading financial centre in Malaya.Throughout the century
column9: George Town's population grew rapidly in tandem with the city's economic prosperity. A cosmopolitan
column10: multi-cultural population emerged
column12: Malay
column13: Indian
column14: Peranakan
column17: the population growth also created social problems
column18: such as inadequate sanitation and public health facilities
column19: as well as rampant crime. The latter culminated in the Penang Riots of 1867
column20: during which rival Chinese triads clashed in the streets of George Town.Also in the same year
column21: the Straits Settlements was made a British crown colony
column22: to be governed directly by the Colonial Office in London. For George Town
column23: direct British rule meant better law enforcement
column24: as the police force was vastly improved and the secret societies that had previously plagued the city were gradually outlawed. More investments were also made on the city's health care and public transportation.With improved access to education
column25: a greater level of participation in municipal affairs by its Asian residents and substantial press freedom
column26: George Town was perceived as being more intellectually receptive than Singapore. The city became a magnet for well known English authors

column1: At the start of World War I in 1914
column2: the Battle of Penang occurred
column3: during which SMS Emden
column4: an Imperial German Navy cruiser
column5: sank two Allied warships off the coast of George Town. 147 French and Russian sailors were killed.World War II
column6: on the other hand
column7: brought unparalleled social and political upheaval to Penang. In early December 1941
column8: Japanese warplanes indiscriminately strafed and bombed George Town
column9: and wiped out the defending Allied air squadrons. While the British Army had earlier designated Penang Island as a fortress
column10: Lieutenant-General Arthur Percival then ordered a withdrawal from Penang. Not only did the British abandon the Batu Maung Fort south of the city
column11: they also covertly evacuated Penang's European population
column12: leaving the rest of the populace to their fates. Historians have since argued that the withdrawal and the silent evacuation of the white race led to the loss of the British sense of invincibility
column13: and that the moral collapse of British rule in Southeast Asia came not in Singapore
column14: but in Penang.George Town fell to the Imperial Japanese Army on 19 December 1941
column15: marking the start of a brutal period of Japanese occupation. Penang Island was renamed Tojo-to
column16: after the then Japanese Prime Minister Hideki Tojo. This period was known for the Imperial Japanese Army's massacres of Penang's Chinese populace
column17: known as Sook Ching to the locals. Women in George Town were also coerced to work as comfort women by the Japanese.George Town's harbour facilities were also put to use as a major U-boat base by Nazi Germany. Between 1942 and 1944
column18: the Port of Penang was utilised by submarines of the Imperial Japanese Navy
column19: the Kriegsmarine and the Regia Marina.Between 1944 and 1945
column20: Allied bombers based in India repeatedly bombed George Town
column21: seeking to destroy the naval facilities and administrative centres. Several colonial buildings were destroyed or damaged
column24: Hutchings School (now Penang State Museum) and the Penang Secretariat Building. The Penang Strait was also mined to impede Japanese shipping.Following the Japanese surrender on 15 August 1945
column27: published the proclamation of surrender issued by the Emperor of Japan. Under Operation Jurist
column28: the British Royal Marines accepted the surrender of the Japanese garrison in Penang and retook Penang Island on 3 September 1945.

column1: After a period of military administration
column2: the British dissolved the Straits Settlements in 1946 and proceeded to merge the Crown Colony of Penang into the Malayan Union
column3: which was then replaced with the Federation of Malaya in 1948. However
column4: the absorption of the British colony of Penang into Malaya alarmed Penang's population over economic and ethnic concerns. Between 1948 and 1951
column5: the Penang Secessionist Committee was formed to avert Penang's merger with Malaya
column6: but ultimately petered out due to British disapproval.The British government responded to the concerns raised by the secessionists by guaranteeing George Town's free port status
column7: as well as reintroducing municipal elections in George Town in 1951. By 1956
column8: George Town had become the first municipality in the Malayan Federation to have a fully elected local council.On 1 January 1957
column9: George Town was accorded city status by Queen Elizabeth II
column10: becoming the first city within the Federation of Malaya
column12: Malaysia.

column2: George Town retained its free port status
column3: as guaranteed by the British colonial authorities before granting independence to Malaya. This was not to last
column4: however – in 1969
column5: the Malaysian federal government revoked George Town's free port status
column6: sparking massive unemployment in the city.This also marked the start of George Town's decline
column7: which lasted up to the early 2000s. As the Malaysian federal government continued to develop Kuala Lumpur and nearby Port Klang
column8: Penang began to suffer considerable brain drain.In a bid to revitalise George Town
column9: the Komtar project was launched in 1974. Hundreds of shophouses
column10: schools and temples
column12: were demolished in order to make way for the construction of Penang's tallest skyscraper. However
column13: instead of arresting George Town's decline
column14: Komtar itself became a white elephant by the 2000s.In 1974
column15: the George Town City Council was merged with the Penang Island Rural District Council to form the Penang Island Municipal Council
column16: sparking a decades-long debate over George Town's city status.

column1: The city's decline continued into the early 2000s. In 2001
column2: the Rent Control Act
column3: which had protected the low-income residents and smaller businesses within the city centre from arbitrary rental hikes
column4: was repealed. Consequently
column5: residents moved out of the city's historical core
column6: leaving its colonial-era buildings in disrepair. Meanwhile
column7: an incoherent urban planning policy and poor traffic management led to worsening traffic congestion
column8: while decades of brain drain also took its toll as the city lacked the expertise to regulate urban development.In response
column9: George Town's non-governmental organisations and the national press galvanised public support and formed strategic partnerships for the conservation of the historic buildings
column10: and to restore the city to its former glory. As a result of the widespread resentment over George Town's decline
column12: Pakatan Rakyat (now Pakatan Harapan)
column13: was voted into power within Penang in the 2008 State Election.Also in 2008
column14: George Town was inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Subsequent efforts to clean up the city
column15: and measures to improve traffic flow
column16: cultural and environmental aspects by the new state government led to George Town being ranked Asia's 8th most liveable city by ECA International in 2010. The city's services sector has since been boosted by the private sector and an influx of foreign investors.The Indian Ocean tsunami which struck in 2004 hit the western and northern coasts of Penang Island
column18: claiming 52 lives (out of 68 in Malaysia).Whilst George Town had been declared a city by Queen Elizabeth II in 1957
column19: the jurisdiction of the city was expanded by the Malaysian federal government to encompass the entirety of Penang Island in 2015.

column1: The jurisdiction of George Town covers an area of 305.77 km2 (118.06 sq mi)
column2: encompassing the entirety of Penang Island and five of the surrounding islets
column3: including Jerejak Island. George Town is only slightly more than a third the size of Singapore with a population density of 2
column5: 140/sq mi); thus the city has one of the highest population densities of all Malaysian cities.The contiguous hotel and resort belts of Batu Ferringhi and Tanjung Bungah and Tanjung Tokong along the northern beaches of Penang Island form the northwestern fringes of George Town. The central hills of Penang Island
column6: including Penang Hill
column7: serve as a giant green lung for George Town and an important forested catchment area. While the central hills have somewhat limited the westward urban sprawl
column8: George Town's expansion is more evident southward along the eastern seaboard of Penang Island
column9: creating the suburbs of Jelutong and Gelugor
column10: the latter merging with the northward development of Bayan Lepas.As with most island cities
column11: land scarcity is a pressing issue in George Town. Land reclamation projects have been carried out to provide more low-lying land at high-demand areas
column12: such as at Gurney Drive
column13: Tanjung Tokong and Jelutong.

column1: The oldest portion of the city centre has been designated by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site since 2008. Recognised as having a "unique architectural and cultural townscape without parallel anywhere in East and Southeast Asia"
column2: George Town contains one of the largest collections of pre-war buildings in Southeast Asia.The World Heritage Site covers nearly 260 ha (2.6 km2) of the city centre
column3: roughly bounded by Transfer Road to the west and Prangin Road to the south. The zone includes the city's administrative precinct
column4: which is home to the most historic landmarks like Fort Cornwallis
column5: City Hall and the Penang State Museum
column6: as well as the main Central Business District along Beach Street. The zone also covers various places of worship
column7: such as St. George's Church
column8: the Kapitan Keling Mosque and the Goddess of Mercy Temple
column9: as well as the Cheong Fatt Tze Mansion and the Eastern & Oriental Hotel.Among the restrictions in force within the zone is a ban on the construction of any structure exceeding 18 m (59 ft) in height
column10: and that any new building which is located adjacent to a historically important structure must not exceed the height of the latter.

column2: George Town still retains most of its English street names. Even for roads that have been renamed in Malay
column3: such as Jalan Masjid Negeri
column4: Penangites in general still prefer to use the road's former colonial name
column5: which in this particular case is Green Lane. This is partly because the new names are often unwieldy (e.g. Pitt Street vs Jalan Masjid Kapitan Keling
column6: Northam Road vs Jalan Sultan Ahmad Shah)
column7: but also reflects a strong conservatism in the local population
column8: who see Penang's colonial history as part of their local identity.Since 2008
column9: multi-lingual road signs have been in use throughout Penang Island. Each of the new road signs shows the street's official Malay name and either the street's English
column10: Chinese

column1: The most popular beaches of George Town are situated along the city's northwestern suburbs
column2: specifically Batu Ferringhi
column3: Tanjung Bungah and Tanjung Tokong. Several hotels and resorts have been established along these locations
column4: including Hard Rock Hotel. Aside from these

column6: the Esplanade and Karpal Singh Drive. In particular

column8: and is a shopping haven with two upmarket shopping malls – Gurney Plaza and Gurney Paragon. Land reclamation is currently ongoing off Gurney Drive in a state-led effort to create a seafront public park
column9: named Gurney Wharf.

column1: The central hills of Penang Island
column2: situated to the west of George Town
column3: serve as a gigantic green lung and water catchment area for the urbanised island. Rising 833 m (2
column4: 733 ft) above sea level
column5: the peak of Penang Hill is accessible via the Penang Hill Railway from its base station off Hill Railway Road. Once a retreat used by British officials and Queen Elizabeth II
column6: Penang Hill is one of Penang's most well-known tourist attractions.

column1: Founded in 1884 as an offshoot of the Singapore Botanic Gardens
column2: the Penang Botanic Gardens is Malaysia's oldest botanical garden. Today
column3: it serves as a major recreational area
column4: receiving about 5
column5: 000 visitors every weekend. This botanical garden also encompasses Penang's biggest waterfall
column6: which forms part of George Town's water supply. Meanwhile
column7: the nearby 172-acre (70 ha) City Park was officially opened in 1972.The city is also home to the world's smallest national park – the Penang National Park. Covering 2
column8: 562 ha (25.62 km2) of the northwestern tip of Penang Island
column9: it contains mangrove swamps
column10: rainforest interspersed with hiking trails and tranquil beaches. Other notable natural attractions nearby include the Tropical Spice Garden and the Entopia Butterfly Farm
column11: the latter of which was Malaysia's first butterfly sanctuary.

column1: The city features a tropical rainforest climate
column2: under the Köppen climate classification (Af). George Town experiences relatively consistent temperatures throughout the course of the year
column3: with an average high of about 32 °C (90 °F) and an average low of 21 °C (70 °F). The city sees on average about 2
column4: 477 millimetres (97.5 in) of precipitation annually.George Town's proximity to the island of Sumatra makes it susceptible to dust particles carried by wind from the perennial but transient forest fires
column5: creating a yearly phenomenon known as the Southeast Asian haze.Weather forecast in George Town is served by the Penang Meteorological Office in Bayan Lepas
column6: which acts as the primary weather forecast facility for northern Peninsular Malaysia.

column1: Local administration of George Town and all of Penang Island is carried out by the Penang Island City Council
column2: which comes under the purview of the Penang state government. With a history dating back to 1800
column3: it is Malaysia's oldest local government and the successor to the nation's first city council – the George Town City Council.Headquartered in the City Hall
column4: the city council is responsible for urban planning
column5: heritage preservation
column6: public health
column7: sanitation
column8: waste management
column9: traffic management
column10: environmental protection
column12: social and economic development
column13: and general maintenance of urban infrastructure. In 2018
column14: George Town was recognised as one of the cleanest cities in ASEAN
column15: following a 2017 ranking which placed George Town as Malaysia's second cleanest city.The Mayor of Penang Island is appointed by the Penang state government every two years
column16: while each of the 24 councillors is appointed for a one-year term. The current Mayor is Yew Tung Seang
column17: who took office in 2018. Penang-based non-governmental organisations are also allocated four of the 24 councillor positions.

column24: Pulau Betong and Telok Bahang. The members of the State Legislative Assembly

column1: The Malaysian legal system had its roots in George Town. By 1807
column2: Penang was accorded a Royal Charter which provided for the establishment of a Supreme Court and the appointment of the first Supreme Court judge
column3: designated as the Recorder.The Supreme Court of Penang (now High Court of Penang) was first opened at Fort Cornwallis on 31 May 1808. Edmond Stanley assumed office as the First Recorder of the Supreme Court of Penang in 1808
column4: thus serving as Malaya's first Superior Court Judge. The Supreme Court was then relocated a short distance away to Light Street
column5: where the present building was built in 1903.Today
column6: the Malaysian judiciary has become largely centralised. The courts in George Town consist of the Magistrates
column7: Sessions and the High Court
column8: the latter of which sits at the top of Penang's judicial system. The High Court remains at Light Street to this day
column9: along with the Magistrates and Sessions Court across the street. Another Sessions Court has also been established in Balik Pulau to the west.

column2: George Town had a population of 708
column3: 127. More recent estimates from Malaysia's Department of Statistics indicated that about 738

column1: According to Malaysia's Department of Statistics
column2: George Town is a Chinese-majority city; as of 2010
column3: over 53% of the urban population consisted of ethnic Chinese
column4: including the Peranakans. The Bumiputeras
column5: which include ethnic Malays and East Malaysian indigenous races like the Dayaks and Kadazans
column6: collectively made up almost 32% of the city's population. Ethnic Indians comprised another 9% of George Town's population. These are in addition to small
column7: but prominent
column8: Eurasian and Siamese minorities. In particular
column9: most of the nearly 1
column10: 500 Eurasians remain concentrated at the Pulau Tikus suburb.The Peranakans
column11: descendants of mixed Malay and Chinese ancestries
column12: were once the political and business elites in George Town. They held the top positions in some of the city's most influential associations
column13: such as the Penang Chinese Chamber of Commerce and the Penang Straits Chinese British Association. As the Peranakans tended to be more loyal to the British Crown than to China
column14: they were also known as the King's Chinese. In spite of Malaysia's ethnic policies that have effectively forced the Peranakans to identify themselves as Chinese
column15: Peranakan culture still thrives in George Town to this day
column16: in the form of Straits Chinese architectural styles and dishes like asam laksa.George Town currently has a sizeable expatriate population
column18: Japan and various Asian countries as well as the United Kingdom
column19: many of whom chose to retire in Penang as part of Malaysia My Second Home programme. In recent years
column20: George Town has been acknowledged as one of the best cities for retirement within Southeast Asia by the likes of CNN and Forbes. As of 2010
column21: expatriates made up nearly 6% of George Town's population
column22: reflecting the city's popularity amongst foreigners.

column1: The city was also once home to Burmese
column2: Filipino
column3: Sinhalese
column4: Japanese
column5: Sumatran
column6: Arab
column7: Armenian and Persian communities. A small but commercially significant community of German merchants existed in George Town as well
column8: as did a Jewish enclave. Even though most of these other communities
column9: including the Jews

column1: As with other multi-ethnic cities in Malaysia
column2: all four major languages are widely spoken in George Town – Malay
column3: English
column4: Chinese and Tamil. However
column5: George Town
column6: and by extension Penang
column7: is best known for its distinct Hokkien dialect
column8: known as Penang Hokkien.During the British colonial era
column9: English was the official language. This was helped by the mushrooming of missionary schools throughout George Town
column10: all of which used English as their medium of instruction and were held in high esteem by the locals. Most Penangites still maintain reasonable command of the language; while British English is formally used
column11: spoken English usually takes the form of Manglish.As in the rest of Malaysia
column12: Malay is currently the official language in George Town. The city's Malays also use a variant of the Kedah Malay dialect
column13: with slight modifications made to the original dialect to suit the conditions of a cosmopolitan city. These modifications include the use of words of Indian origin and the alteration of the final l syllable into i.Due to their Tamil ancestry
column14: most Indians in George Town speak Tamil. Punjabi and Telugu are also spoken by smaller numbers of Indians. Meanwhile
column15: George Town's Chinese population uses a variety of Chinese dialects
column18: has been the medium of instruction in Chinese schools throughout Penang.However
column19: Penang Hokkien serves as the lingua franca of George Town. Originally a variant of the Minnan dialect
column21: Penang Hokkien has incorporated a large number of loanwords from Malay and English. It is spoken by many Penangites regardless of race for communication purposes. In recent years
column22: there have been more efforts to maintain the dialect's relevance in the face of the increasing influence of Mandarin and English among the younger populace.

column7: of Malaysia's personal disposable income in 2015

column1: With nearly ​3⁄5 of Penang's workforce employed in services-related fields
column2: the services sector has marginally overtaken manufacturing as Penang's biggest economic sector
column3: contributing 49.3% of Penang's total GDP in 2017. The largest share of employment was recorded in the retail
column4: accommodation
column5: and food and beverages (F&B) sub-sectors
column6: clearly depicting the influence of tourist arrivals on service-related industries. Since the inscription of George Town as a UNESCO World Heritage Site
column7: an emerging trend is the acquisition of heritage shophouses within the zone by foreign investors
column8: especially from Singapore and Hong Kong.In addition
column9: a startup community has been growing in the city
column10: which include the likes of Piktochart and DeliverEat. Attracted by the city's cheaper living costs and the presence of several multinational technology firms in Penang
column11: the city's startups are also being actively encouraged by the Penang state government and the private sector
column12: with initiatives to encourage entrepreneurship and promote the Internet of Things (IoT).This services sector has also been boosted by firms seeking to establish shared services outsourcing (SSO) operations within or around George Town
column13: including AirAsia
column14: Citigroup
column17: Penang has emerged as the second most important Global Business Services (GBS) hub within Malaysia

column1: An integral part of Penang's services sector is medical tourism
column2: which has made George Town the medical tourism hub of Malaysia. The city has attracted approximately half of Malaysia's medical tourist arrivals in 2013 and generated about 70% of the nation's medical tourism revenue. About 1
column3: 000 patients arrive in George Town daily
column4: mostly from Asian countries such as Indonesia
column5: Singapore and Japan.The success of George Town's medical tourism industry is mainly due to the specialised medical treatments offered at more affordable costs by the city's numerous private hospitals
column6: coupled with well-trained professionals and advanced equipment. Indirect factors that were cited include the relatively low cost of living and the ease of travel facilitated by the well-developed logistical infrastructure.

column1: As many as 24% of Penang's workforce are employed in the retail sub-sector
column2: the largest of all economic sub-sectors in Penang. Due to the numerous shopping malls and hypermarkets in George Town
column3: the city is the main shopping hub of northern Malaysia. Since 2001
column4: shopping complexes in George Town registered the biggest increases in Malaysia. Among the more well-known shopping malls within the city are Gurney Plaza
column5: Gurney Paragon
column6: 1st Avenue and Queensbay Mall.While shopping malls now dominate the retail scene in George Town
column7: many centuries-old shophouses are still operating alongside the city's flea markets and wet markets
column8: such as Chowrasta Market. These traditional retail establishments cater more to locally made products
column9: including spices
column10: nutmegs and tau sar pneah

column1: Centuries of development have brought a mix of architectural styles to George Town
column2: both historical and modern. The oldest portion of the city centre is a UNESCO World Heritage Site
column3: while outside the UNESCO zone lies the modern cityscape
column4: with skyscrapers
column5: residential high-rises
column6: office blocks and shopping malls built all over the city.

column1: Most of George Town's famous heritage landmarks
column2: including Fort Cornwallis
column3: the City Hall
column4: the High Court
column5: St. George's Church and the Eastern & Oriental Hotel are located within the UNESCO World Heritage Site. The city's main Central Business District at Beach Street
column6: also within the UNESCO zone
column7: is home to banks built in various Art Deco-based hybrid styles. Colonial-era bungalows
column8: such as The Residency and Suffolk House
column9: can be found throughout the city as well.Aside from colonial European architecture
column10: a huge assortment of Asian architectural styles also exist throughout the city. Buildings like the Kapitan Keling Mosque
column11: Cheong Fatt Tze Mansion and the Pinang Peranakan Mansion are notable for their architectural styles
column12: which combine diverse cultural influences. Peranakan townhouses
column13: exemplified by the Sun Yat-sen Museum
column14: dominate the cityscape as well. Meanwhile
column15: Indian architecture is more prominent within the city's Little India
column16: which also contains the Sri Mahamariamman Temple.In the suburbs
column17: the Siamese and Burmese communities have left their mark too; the Buddhist temples at Pulau Tikus include Wat Chaiyamangkalaram and the Dhammikarama Temple. Another example of a hybrid Asian architecture is the Kek Lok Si Temple at Air Itam

column2: modern urbanisation has transformed much of George Town. Just south of the UNESCO World Heritage Site stands the Komtar Tower
column3: the tallest skyscraper in Penang at nearly 250 m (820 ft) tall. The second Central Business District at Northam Road and Gurney Drive
column4: which lies along the city's northern shoreline
column5: is also home to some of Penang's tallest skyscrapers
column6: including Setia V
column7: Gurney Paragon and BHL Tower.With increasing urbanisation
column8: high-rises are also springing up within the suburbs of George Town.

column2: long known as the food capital of Malaysia
column3: is renowned for its good and varied street food
column4: incorporating Malay
column5: Chinese
column6: Indian
column7: Peranakan
column8: Thai and European influences into its literal melting pot.The city has been recognised as one of Asia's top street food cities by CNN
column9: as well the world's top culinary destination by the Lonely Planet in 2014. These were in addition to the Time magazine in 2004
column10: which acclaimed Penang as having the best street food in Asia.The best places to savour street cuisine include Gurney Drive
column12: Chulia Street
column13: Kimberley Street
column14: New Lane
column16: Penang Road and Air Itam. The more prominent local dishes include asam laksa
column23: several tau sar pneah shops can be found throughout the city

column1: George Town is the birthplace of a unique form of Chingay procession
column2: which began with its first parade in 1919. Penang's variant of Chingay includes the act of balancing gigantic flags on one's forehead or hands. An annual Chingay parade is held in the city every December
column3: though Chingay performances are also a common feature of Chinese festivities and major state celebrations in Penang.Bangsawan is a form of Malay theatre which was developed in Penang with Indian
column4: Western
column5: Islamic
column6: Chinese and Indonesian influences. It went into decline in the latter decades of the 20th century and is now a dying art form. Boria is another traditional dance drama indigenous to Penang
column7: featuring singing accompanied by violin
column8: maracas and tabla.Aside from these
column9: there are two Western orchestras based in George Town – the Penang Philharmonic and the Penang Symphony Orchestra (PSO) – as well as several chamber and school-based musical ensembles. Dewan Sri Pinang and Penangpac within Straits Quay are two of the major performing venues in the city.

column2: as part of the annual George Town Festival
column3: Lithuanian artist Ernest Zacharevic created a series of wall murals depicting local culture
column4: inhabitants and lifestyles. They now stand as celebrated cultural landmarks of George Town
column5: with Children on a Bicycle becoming one of the most photographed spots in the city.Since then
column6: the street art scene has blossomed. Arts exhibitions are held at the city's numerous cultural centres
column7: such as the Hin Bus Depot. Aside from wall art
column8: several wrought iron caricatures
column9: each depicting a unique aspect of George Town's history and culture
column10: have been installed throughout the city centre.

column1: The Penang State Museum and Art Gallery houses relics
column2: photographs
column3: maps
column4: and other artifacts that document the history and culture of Penang. Other museums within the city focus on religious and cultural aspects
column5: as well as famous personalities
column6: including the Penang Islamic Museum
column7: Sun Yat-sen Museum
column8: P. Ramlee's House
column9: Batik Painting Museum
column10: and Universiti Sains Malaysia Museum and Gallery.In recent years
column11: private-run museums have sprung up all over the city
column12: such as the Camera Museum and the Penang Toy Museum. A handful of newer visual museums have also been launched
column13: such as the Made-in-Penang Interactive Museum and the Penang Time Tunnel.

column1: George Town's cultural melting pot of various races and religions means that there are a great many celebrations and festivities in any given year. The major cultural and religious festivities in George Town include
column2: but not limited to
column3: the Chinese New Year
column4: Chap Goh Meh
column5: Songkran
column6: Wesak Day
column7: Seventh Month Festival
column8: Nine Emperor Gods Festival
column9: Eid ul-Fitri
column10: Deepavali
column12: Vaisakhi and Christmas.The city's expatriates have introduced a host of other celebrations as well. Bon Odori is celebrated yearly at the Esplanade by the Japanese
column13: while St. Patrick's Day and Oktoberfest
column14: traditionally celebrated by the Irish and the Germans respectively
column15: have also been gaining popularity amongst the locals.In addition
column16: the city hosts several major festivals in any given year. The George Town Festival
column18: has evolved into one of the top arts events in Southeast Asia
column19: while the Penang Hot Air Balloon Fiesta attracts close to 200
column20: 000 visitors from all over the world.

column1: George Town has a relatively well-developed sporting infrastructure. The City Stadium is Penang Island's main football stadium
column2: with a capacity of about 25
column3: 000. It is the home ground of Penang FA
column4: and was where Penang footballer Mohd Faiz Subri scored the goal that won him the 2016 FIFA Puskás Award. The SPICE Arena at Bayan Baru consists of an indoor stadium
column5: an aquatics centre and a convention centre
column6: while the Nicol David International Squash Centre at Gelugor is a major squash training facility. In addition
column7: the Penang Turf Club
column8: established in 1864
column9: is Malaysia's oldest horse racing and equestrian centre.[232]The Penang Bridge International Marathon is a popular annual event. The full marathon route starts from near Queensbay Mall
column10: then on to the 13.5 km (8.4 mi) length of the Penang Bridge
column11: and finally back to the starting point for the finish.The national and international sporting events that were held in George Town include the 2001 Southeast Asian Games and the 2013 Women's World Open Squash Championship. In addition
column12: George Town will host the Asia Pacific Masters Games in 2018
column13: the first Malaysian city to be selected to host this regional multi-sports tournament.

column1: George Town is home to some of the oldest schools in Malaysia
column2: making it a pioneer in the country's education system. Under British rule
column3: missionary schools were set up across George Town. They were followed by Chinese schools
column4: some of which are also among the oldest in the nation
column5: thus making George Town the nucleus of Chinese education in Southeast Asia. More recently
column6: international schools have also been established to cater to the growing expatriate population.

column2: George Town contains a number of private tertiary educational institutions
column3: as well as one of the premier Malaysian public universities – Universiti Sains Malaysia. Aside from these
column4: the city has a handful of language institutions
column5: such as the British Council
column6: Alliance Française and the Malaysian German Society.

column1: There are a total of 117 primary schools
column2: 49 high schools
column3: four Islamic religious schools
column4: two vocational colleges and a technical school throughout George Town. The breakdown of these schools is as follows.

column1: Some of the oldest missionary schools in George Town include the Penang Free School
column2: St. Xavier's Institution
column3: Convent Light Street
column4: St. George's Girls' School and Methodist Boys' School. Meanwhile
column5: the Chung Hwa Confucian School
column6: founded in 1904
column7: was the first Chinese school in Southeast Asia.Aside from government-run and private schools
column8: the city has 11 international schools. Of these
column9: Dalat
column10: Uplands
column12: Fairview
column13: Pelita
column14: Hua Xia and Wesley Methodist offer both primary and secondary education. The Penang Japanese School is the only international school in George Town that caters for expatriates of a specific nationality.

column2: situated at Gelugor
column3: is one of the premier Malaysian public universities. Established in 1969 as Malaysia's second university
column4: it was originally named Universiti Pulau Pinang (University of Penang). As of 2018
column5: it was ranked 207th in the QS World University Rankings
column6: the fourth highest in Malaysia.Several private universities and colleges have also been set up across George Town
column7: including Wawasan Open University

column9: Han Chiang University College of Communication

column1: George Town contains a total of 30 libraries. Among the libraries in the city are the Penang State Library at Scotland Road and the Penang Digital Library at Green Lane. The latter
column2: which was opened by the Penang state government in 2016
column3: is Malaysia's first digital library and houses a digitalised collection of over 3
column4: 000 publications.

column1: The numerous public and private hospitals in George Town has helped the city to emerge as the centre of medical tourism in Malaysia. The Penang General Hospital
column2: administered and funded by the Ministry of Health
column3: is the main public hospital in George Town and serves as the tertiary referral hospital within northern Malaysia. It is complemented by the Balik Pulau Hospital
column4: which is also managed by the country's Ministry of Health.There are also 54 government-run clinics throughout George Town
column5: supported by 11 private hospitals and 352 private clinics. The private hospitals within George Town include Penang Adventist Hospital
column6: Island Hospital
column7: Gleneagles Medical Centre
column8: Loh Guan Lye Specialists Centre
column9: Lam Wah Ee Hospital
column10: Mount Miriam Cancer Hospital and Pantai Hospital.

column1: George Town became the first Malaysian city to install public automated external defibrillators (AEDs)
column2: with the launch of the first device in Komtar in 2015. Since then
column3: AEDs have been installed at several public locations throughout the city.

column1: George Town was once the centre of Malaysia's print media. The country's first newspaper – the Prince of Wales Island Gazette – was established in the city in 1806. One of Malaysia's top dailies currently in circulation
column2: The Star
column3: was founded in George Town in the 1970s
column4: while the country's oldest Chinese newspaper
column5: Kwong Wah Yit Poh
column6: was also founded in the city in 1910.In 2011
column7: the then Chief Minister of Penang
column8: Lim Guan Eng
column9: officiated the launch of the Penang edition of Time Out. This version of the international listings magazine is currently published in three versions – an annual guide
column10: a website and a mobile app.The Penang state government also publishes its own multi-lingual newspaper
column12: which is circulated for free every fortnight. The Penang-centric newspaper focuses on the current issues affecting Penang.

column1: Due to its well-preserved heritage cityscape
column2: George Town served as the filming location for a number of movies
column3: such as Anna and the King
column4: Lust
column5: Caution and You Mean the World to Me
column6: the latter of which is the first movie to be filmed entirely in Penang Hokkien. Singaporean drama series
column7: The Little Nyonya and The Journey: Our Homeland

column9: the city was one of the pit-stops of The Amazing Race 16
column10: The Amazing Race Asia 4 and The Amazing Race Asia 5.

column1: Development of George Town's streets and roads is an ongoing process that dates back to the early years of British rule. The city's oldest streets
column2: including Light Street
column3: Beach Street
column4: Chulia Street and Pitt Street
column5: were arranged in a grid pattern.The Tun Dr Lim Chong Eu Expressway runs along the eastern coastline of Penang Island between the city centre and the Penang International Airport
column6: linking both locations with the Bayan Lepas Free Industrial Zone and the Penang Bridge. The George Town Inner Ring Road and the Penang Middle Ring Road are the two major ring roads around the city centre. The city centre is also linked with the western parts of Penang Island
column7: such as Balik Pulau
column8: via the pan-island Federal Route 6.

column1: Both the 13.5 km (8.4 mi)-long Penang Bridge and the 24 km (15 mi)-long Second Penang Bridge link George Town with the rest of Peninsular Malaysia. The former bridge was completed in 1985
column2: while the latter
column3: opened in 2014
column4: is currently the longest bridge in Southeast Asia.

column1: George Town was once a pioneer of public transportation in British Malaya. The city's first tram system
column2: then powered by steam
column3: commenced operations in the 1880s. While the tram lines have since been disused
column4: another colonial legacy
column5: the trishaw
column6: remains in use throughout the city
column7: albeit catering primarily for tourists.Today
column8: buses form the backbone of public transportation within George Town. Rapid Penang
column9: with over 30 routes on Penang Island
column10: is the sole public bus service provider within George Town. In addition
column12: known as Hop-On Hop-Off buses
column13: have been introduced for tourists in the city. Meanwhile
column14: the Penang Hill Railway is a funicular railway to the peak of Penang Hill.

column1: Efforts are also being undertaken to promote pedestrianisation and the use of bicycles as a greener transportation mode. Dedicated cycling lanes have been marked throughout the city and in 2016
column2: George Town became the first Malaysian city to operate a public bicycle-sharing service
column3: with the launch of LinkBike.

column2: 16 km (9.9 mi) south of the city centre
column3: was opened in 1935. It serves as the main airport for northern Malaysia
column4: with frequent links to major Asian cities such as Kuala Lumpur
column5: Singapore
column6: Bangkok
column7: Jakarta
column8: Ho Chi Minh City
column9: Taipei
column10: Hong Kong
column11: Guangzhou and Doha. It is also a hub for two Malaysian low-cost carriers – AirAsia and Firefly. The airport is Malaysia's second busiest in terms of cargo traffic and recorded the third highest passenger traffic of all Malaysian airports as of 2013.

column1: The Port of Penang consists of seven facilities along the Penang Strait
column2: including Swettenham Pier in George Town. Renovated in 2009 as a cruise shipping terminal
column3: Swettenham Pier is one of the major tourist entry points into George Town. As of 2017
column4: the pier recorded 1.35 million tourist arrivals
column5: thereby surpassing Port Klang as the busiest port-of-call in Malaysia for cruise shipping. The pier has also attracted some of the world's largest cruise liners
column6: such as the RMS Queen Mary 2.A number of cruise ships call Swettenham Pier as their homeport
column7: bringing tourists into and out of George Town towards regional destinations like Phuket and Singapore. Occasionally
column8: the pier hosts warships as well
column9: including those from Singapore
column10: Thailand and the United States.

column1: Rapid Ferry is a cross-strait shuttle ferry service that connects George Town with the town of Butterworth on the Malay Peninsula. It is the oldest ferry service in Malaysia
column2: dating back to 1894 when the first passenger ferry commenced operations. Currently
column3: six ferries ply the Penang Strait between George Town and Butterworth daily.

column1: Several nations have either established their consulates or appointed honorary-consulates within George Town.
George Town has eight sister cities.
